glsa.title: Apache: buffer overflows and a possible information disclosure
glsa.synopsis: Multiple stack-based buffer overflows in mod_alias and mod_rewrite can allow execution of arbitrary code and cause a denial of service, and a bug in the way mod_cgid handles CGI redirect paths could result in CGI output going to the wrong client.

background.p: The Apache HTTP Server is one of the most popular web servers on the Internet.

description.p: Multiple stack-based buffer overflows in mod_alias and mod_rewrite allow attackers who can create or edit configuration files including .htaccess files, to cause a denial of service and execute arbitrary code via a regular expression containing more than 9 captures, and a bug in the way mod_cgid handles CGI redirect paths could result in CGI output going to the wrong client when a threaded MPM is used, resulting in an information disclosure.

impact.p: An attacker may cause a denial of service or execute arbitrary code with the privileges of the user that is running apache.

workaround.p: There is no known workaround at this time.

resolution.p: It is recommended that all Gentoo Linux users who are running net-misc/apache 2.x upgrade:
resolution.code: # emerge sync # emerge -pv '>=www-servers/apache-2.0.48' # emerge '>=www-servers/apache-2.0.48' # emerge clean # /etc/init.d/apache2 restart
resolution.p: Please remember to update your config files in /etc/apache2 as --datadir has been changed to /var/www/localhost.
